content.rendered:
What is a Registered Nurse?

Registered Nurses are an integral part of the world of healthcare. There are many different specialties of nurses, but in general they provide care to patients of their specialization. Nurses keep track of the detailed history of a patient’s medical records and needs.

Where does a Registered Nurse work?

  • Hospitals
  • Outpatient clinics
  • Physicians’ offices

How much does a Registered Nurse make?

Based on real new grad salaries reported through Handshake, the median annual salary for a Registered Nurse is $61,498.

What majors are typically interested in becoming Registered Nurses?

One’s major doesn’t necessarily determine their career, but these are some common majors of those who end up pursuing this career path.

  • Nursing majors
  • Biology majors
  • Health services majors
Search Registered Nurse job opportunities on Handshake.

Registered Nurse skills and competencies:

On top of a relevant degree and formal training, here are some professional skills that can help aspiring Registered Nurses succeed in their work:

  • Clinical experience
  • Mastery over taking vitals and other basic duties
  • Ability to stay calm during stressful situations

What are some common questions about Registered Nurses?

Q: How do I become a Registered Nurse (RN)?

A: Complete a registered nursing program, pass the NCLEX-RN exam, and get your state license to practice! After that organize your resume and cover letters and start applying!

excerpt.rendered: Learn about the average salary, relevant studies, and common path after college to becoming a Registered Nurse.
